name: Munich
fun_fact: Fun fact: Munich's beer purity law (Reinheitsgebot) from 1516 is the world's oldest food regulation still in effect - it mandates that beer can only contain water, barley, and hops, and Munich breweries still follow it religiously, making the city's beer gardens living museums of medieval brewing.

hero_dishes.name: Weisswurst with Sweet Mustard and Pretzel
hero_dishes.description: Bavarian veal sausage poached (never grilled) and served with sweet mustard, a pretzel, and Weissbier. The sausage skin is peeled before eating.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Invented in Munich in 1857 when a butcher ran out of sheep intestine for bratwurst and used pork casing instead. The delicate veal mixture couldn't handle frying, so he poached them. Traditionally eaten before noon - locals say 'Weisswurst shouldn't hear the church bells ring at noon.'
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Served at most Bavarian taverns and beer gardens throughout Munich, especially traditional spots like Viktualienmarkt

hero_dishes.name: Schweinshaxe (Pork Knuckle)
hero_dishes.description: Slow-roasted pork knuckle with impossibly crispy skin and tender, juicy meat inside. Served with potato dumplings and sauerkraut.
hero_dishes.origin_story: The ultimate Bavarian beer garden food. The knuckle is roasted for hours until the skin becomes crackling-crispy. It's massive - often over a pound of meat - designed to fuel long afternoons of beer drinking.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Augustiner Keller (over 200 years old, 5,000+ seats), KÃ¶niglicher Hirschgarten (world's largest beer garden)

hero_dishes.name: Obatzda
hero_dishes.description: Bavarian cheese spread made with Camembert, butter, paprika, and onions. Served with pretzels or radishes.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A beer garden staple that transforms leftover Camembert into something magical. The name comes from Bavarian dialect meaning 'mashed up.' It's the perfect accompaniment to beer - salty, creamy, and traditionally eaten in the self-service area of beer gardens.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Self-service areas of beer gardens: Chinesischer Turm (7,000 seats in English Garden), Augustiner Keller, Viktualienmarkt

hero_dishes.name: Steckerlfisch (Grilled Fish on a Stick)
hero_dishes.description: Whole mackerel grilled over an open flame on a wooden stick, brushed with herbs and oil.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Munich beer garden favorite that brings the ocean to landlocked Bavaria. The fish is butterflied, skewered on a stick (Steckerl), and grilled over beechwood, creating a smoky, herbal flavor.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Beer gardens throughout Munich, especially Viktualienmarkt beer garden (central location)

signature_drinks.name: Bavarian Weissbier (Hefeweizen)
signature_drinks.description: Cloudy wheat beer with notes of banana and clove, served in tall vase-shaped glasses.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Always poured correctly - glass tilted, bottle held high, creating a thick foam crown. Drunk year-round but especially refreshing in summer beer gardens. Traditionally paired with Weisswurst for breakfast.

signature_drinks.name: Helles (Munich Lager)
signature_drinks.description: Pale, golden lager that's smooth, malty, and slightly sweet. Munich's everyday beer.

food_culture_notes: Beer gardens have self-service areas where you can bring your own food - it's traditional and perfectly acceptable
The Reinheitsgebot (beer purity law from 1516) is taken seriously - Munich beer contains only water, barley, hops, and yeast
Viktualienmarkt beer garden is unique - it's the only one that doesn't belong to a single brewery; Munich's six breweries take turns
Brass bands play in beer garden towers on sunny days, especially at Chinesischer Turm in the English Garden
